author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
Sorry, why are you registering a package with [this content](https://github.com/qz-michael/QznbTestPackage.jl/blob/980e046dce352c7a6bf71b43db0b49b0742c7a5f/src/QznbTestPackage.jl)?

Hi. Your question prompted me to doubt my method but this was an initial investigation into Julia packaging with PkgTemplates.

The process is straight-forward referencing posts like <https://jaantollander.com/post/how-to-create-software-packages-with-julia-language/> and I decided to push to completion and try out TagBot (which implied registration to me). In retrospect I think a better approach would have been to either flesh out a minimally viable package or publish to a different registry, similar to how [TestPyPI](https://test.pypi.org/) is used.

That it met the guidelines for auto-merging is sufficient to declare a successful test :+1:. I have no actual need to register this test package. Please feel free to close/reject. Thanks, Mike
Ok, thanks for confirming, and welcome!
